Subjective: Right-sided low back pain for 1.5 weeks, progressively worsening. Pain radiates down posterior and lateral right leg to the foot. Constant, severe pain. Associated tingling in same distribution and dull sensation on outer right lower leg. Pain significantly disrupts sleep; unable to get comfortable. Unable to work (supermarket job with heavy lifting) or exercise due to pain. Tried max dose paracetamol and ibuprofen with no relief. No subjective weakness, but pain limits movement. Pertinent negatives: No saddle anesthesia, no bowel or bladder dysfunction. Social: Works at supermarket. ICE: Concern about neighbor who required surgery for similar issue; wants to get rid of pain; asks about need for CT/MRI.
Objective: General: Obvious pain with movement, especially getting on exam table. Back Exam: Inspection normal. No vertebral tenderness to palpation. Lower Extremity Exam: Inspection normal, symmetric. Sensation: Decreased, dull sensation on right leg and foot compared to left. Motor: Strength 5/5 and symmetric throughout lower extremities, though movement is painful on the right. Reflexes: Symmetric and normal. Special Tests: Straight leg raise positive on the right, negative on the left.
Assessment: Right lumbosacral radicular syndrome, secondary to suspected herniated disc. No signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: 1. Explained diagnosis of herniated disc and nerve compression. 2. Medication: Start pregabalin for neuropathic pain, titrate dose slowly. 3. Lifestyle: Refer to physiotherapy for exercises. Advised no driving for at least one week after starting or increasing pregabalin dose. 4. Imaging: No scan needed at this time. 5. Safety Netting: Return immediately for new saddle anesthesia, bowel/bladder incontinence, or significant leg weakness. 6. Follow-up: Telephone appointment in 1 week to review pain control and medication side effects.
